statement.tex: %text A diet food contains at least 80 units of Vit. A and 100 units of minerals. Two foods $F_1$ and $F_2$ are available. Food $F_1$ costs ₹ 4 per unit and $F_2$ costs ₹ 6 per unit. One unit of food $F_1$ contains 3 units of Vit. A and 4 units of minerals. One unit of food $F_2$ contains 6 units of Vit. A and 3 units of minerals. Formulate this as a LPP and find graphically the minimum cost for diet that consists of a mixture of these two foods and also meets the minimum nutritional requirements. %

\\ %text If $N_1$ and $N_2$ units of foods $F_1$ and $F_2$ are required, then given the following % \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline & \text{Vit A/unit} & \text{Minerals/unit} & \text{₹/unit} \\ \hline F_1 & 3 & 4 & 4 \\ \hline F_2 & 6 & 3 & 6 \\ \hline \end{tabular} %text
\underline\text{is the following true}? %
\\ %text Which of the following shows the \underline\text{correct plots} for the constraints we found in Step 1? %
\\ %text Given the graph from Step 2, which of the following correctly shows the \underline\text{feasible region}? %

\\ %text Given the feasible region, what are the \underline\text{feasible points} and what is the \underline\text{minimum cost} for the diet food?
%

reason.tex:
%text We need \underline\text{at least} 80 units of Vit. A and 100 units of minerals.
And with $N_1$ units of $F_1$ and $N_2$ units of $F_2$
% \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline & \text{Vit. A} & \text{Minerals} \\ \hline F_1 & 3N_1 & 4N_1\\ \hline F_2 & 6N_2 & 3N_2 \\ \hline \text{Total} & 3N_1 + 6N_2 & 4N_1 + 3N_2 \\ \hline \end{tabular} %text
And these total must satisfy % \begin{align} 3N_1 + 6N_2 &\geq 80 \\ 4N_1 + 3N_2 &\geq 100 \end{align} %text
\underline\text{while keeping costs $(4N_1 + 6N_2)$ at a minimum}. %

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Constraint} & \text{Line to draw} \\ \hline 3N_1 + 6N_2 \geq 80 & 3N_1 + 6N_2 = 80 \\ \hline 4N_1 + 3N_2 \geq 100 & 4N_1 + 3N_2 = 100 \\ \hline \end{tabular} %text
Plug in \underline{$N_1 = 0$} to get coordinates of \underline\text{$A$ and $B$}. Plug in \underline{$N_2 = 0$} to get coordinates of \underline\text{$D$ and $E$}. Solve the equations of both lines to get $C$. %

%text As both constraints require \underline\text{at least} a minimum value, any feasible point must therefore lie \underline\text{above} both the lines.
Hence, the feasible region will be as shown in the correct option. %

%text The points we should consider are $B,C$ and $E$. They lie in the feasible region. And one of them represents the lowest cost.
% \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Point} & (N_1, N_2) & \text{Cost} = 4N_1 + 6N_2 \\ \hline B & (0,\frac{100}{3}) & ₹ 200 \\ \hline C & (24,\frac{4}{3}) & ₹ 104 \\ \hline E & (\frac{80}{3},0) & ₹ 106\frac{2}{3} \\ \hline \end{tabular} %text
It can be seen that the \underline\text{lowest cost point} is point C with total cost of ₹ 104. %
